definition: big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
coin/money/CL:筆|笔[bi3]/unit of weight, one tenth of a tael 兩|两[liang3]

sentences.english: This does not mean that you cannot make good money on a new form of online communication.
sentences.chinese: 這並不意味着你不能從網上交流的新形式上賺大錢。

sentences.english: Of course, child actors earn big money.
Sometimes Mr. Smith makes a lot of money when he plays the market, and sometimes he loses.
sentences.chinese: 史密斯先生做股票生意有時候賺大錢，有時候虧本。

sentences.english: The opportunity to make real money excites you.
sentences.chinese: 你對賺大錢的機會感到無比興奮。

sentences.english: The real money in trading is made from the one, two or three large trades that develop each year.
sentences.chinese: 真正發財是靠一年那一兩三次賺大錢的買賣。

sentences.english: Vinny is very, very happy to have made money out of football without having any other ability.
sentences.chinese: 維尼非常幸福，他沒有其他能力，卻靠足球賺大錢。

sentences.english: Forbes Magazine, for example, is for people who hope to make more money.
sentences.chinese: 福布斯雜誌是爲了那些希望賺大錢的人而設的。

sentences.english: However, making a fortune is not as easy as answering a question.
sentences.chinese: 然而，想要賺大錢可不像回答問題那麼輕鬆。

sentences.english: Mr. Mead was a Johnny-come-lately who lost an opportunity to get rich.
sentences.chinese: 米德先生是位丟掉過一個賺大錢的機會的新成員。

sentences.english: It's the kind of dream you'd expect from a Web wunderkind .
sentences.chinese: 賺大錢的夢想，只能指望網絡神通了。

sentences.english: In Hollywood, no one dare to tell you which picture will make money for studios.
sentences.chinese: 在好萊塢，沒人敢告訴你哪部片能讓製片廠賺大錢。

sentences.english: There are no big earnings from a recording itself.
sentences.chinese: 灌唱片本身不會賺大錢。

sentences.english: Are you going to university just because you want to make a lot of money in that field?
sentences.chinese: 你上大學是隻是因爲你想在那個領域賺大錢嗎？

sentences.english: Nerds are intelligent, have great earning potential, and they're a lot of fun to be around.
sentences.chinese: 書呆子們都是有才智的，並且他們具備賺大錢的潛力。

definition: to take it up a notch/to bring it up a level
high denomination of banknotes or coins/lots of money/a big sum (e.g. a bribe)
to have one's feet firmly planted on the ground (idiom); realistic without flights of fancy/steady and serious character
to be successful in business/professional success
lit. to return to office after living as a hermit on Mount Dongshan (idiom); fig. to make a comeback
everything is going smoothly/just as one wishes
to continue the struggle (idiom); to persist/unremitting efforts
